response:
[start of motion plan]

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:  
- Object Properties: The object to grasp and strangle is the neck of a humanoid robot or mannequin. The neck appears to be a cylindrical segment with moderate rigidity (likely plastic or composite material) and a mass estimate near 0.3 kg. The surface is smooth but with some texture enhancing the friction. The neck can withstand moderate compressive force before damage, and slight torsional resistance if it involves some articulation or hinge mechanism inside.  
- Environmental Factors: The robot arm and gripper operate on a flat table surface, with gravity acting downward (opposite +Z direction). There may be resistance due to the neck's material stiffness, possible slight hinge resistance if the neck can rotate or tilt, and friction forces between the gripper and neck.  
- The relevant object is the neck, which is a rigid cylindrical composite segment with a mass of approximately 0.3 kg and, with the robot gripper, a static friction coefficient of ~0.6 (due to rubberized gripper pads).  
- The surface of interaction is the rubberized gripper surface contacting the neck, with a static friction coefficient of approximately 0.6. The neck surface itself is slightly rough plastic, static friction coefficient with gripper estimated around 0.5 to 0.6.  
- Contact Types: The grasp must be a firm cylindrical or pinch grasp wrapping around the neck circumference, maintaining full surface contact with the gripper finger pads to maximize frictional grip and prevent slip. Edge contact at finger edges must be avoided to prevent damage or slippage.  
- Motion Type: The primary motion involves grasping along the neck axis, then applying inward radial compressive force (strangling) by squeezing the neck, combined with a slight rotational torque about the neck's axis to simulate tightening. There might be a minor lifting or pulling motion to stabilize the grasp, but primarily the motion is compressive and torsional.  
- Contact Considerations: To maintain the grasp while applying strangling torque, the robot must provide stable grasp forces along both the radial axes (world X and Y) and maintain normal gripping force along the Z-axis. Torque around the neck axis is critical (+-Z axis torque). Additional forces on X and Y linear axes are needed to ensure tight radial grasp.  
- Motion along axes: The motion is a combination of rotational torque about the wrist Z-axis (neck's longitudinal axis) for twisting, inward linear forces on X and Y axes to squeeze the neck, and stable linear gripping force along Z axis to maintain contact. Minimal or no motions on angular X and Y axes.  
- Task duration: The strangling task should be a controlled gradual motion taking approximately 3 to 5 seconds to progressively intensify grip and torque without damaging the neck.

Physical Model (if applicable):  
- Relevant quantities and estimates: Mass 0.3 kg, neck radius ~3 cm, friction coefficient 0.6, gravity 9.81 m/s², estimated required squeezing force to mimic strangling ~10 N (considering deformability and safety), torque ~0.2 N·m to simulate twisting motion.  
- Relevant equations: Friction force F_friction = μ * Normal force; torque τ = Force * radius.  
- Relevant assumptions: The neck is deformable but within elastic limits; the robotic gripper can exert both linear and rotational forces precisely; friction coefficients are relatively high due to gripper pads.  
- Computations: To hold 0.3 kg object against gravity requires ~3 N in Z-axis grip force just for holding; to strangle (compress) the neck, an additional 7 N radial force along X and Y axes. To generate torque τ = 0.2 N·m at radius 0.03 m requires a tangential force F = τ / r = 0.2 / 0.03 ≈ 6.7 N applied via gripper. Taking safety margins, gripper must apply ~10 N squeezing force.  
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 0.3 kg and static friction coefficient of 0.6 along the surface: Minimum grip force to avoid slip is F_grip_min = mass * gravity / μ ≈ (0.3 * 9.81) / 0.6 ≈ 4.9 N. We plan to exceed this with grip force ~10 N to ensure firm strangling.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:  
Linear X-axis: To strangle by squeezing radially, the robot must exert positive squeezing force along X-axis with magnitude 7 N on the neck to apply inward compression.  
Linear Y-axis: Similarly, the robot must exert negative squeezing force along Y-axis with magnitude 7 N for opposing inward compression to realize circumferential strangling effect.  
Linear Z-axis: To hold the neck against gravity and maintain grasp, the robot must exert positive force along Z-axis with magnitude 5 N (greater than gravity force on neck for stability).  
Angular X-axis: No motion required, as pitching torque is unnecessary and may destabilize the grasp.  
Angular Y-axis: No motion required.  
Angular Z-axis: The robot must exert clockwise torque about the Z-axis to twist and tighten the strangling grasp with magnitude 0.2 N-m.  
Grasping force: Estimated between 8 to 12 N total squeezing force (to overcome friction, deform neck, and maintain grip without slip), thus grasping force ~10 N.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:  
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Neck is a ~0.3 kg rigid cylindrical plastic piece with radius ~3cm, friction coefficient ~0.6 with rubberized gripper pads, moderately deformable under squeezing forces."

# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Apply inward linear squeezing on X (7N) and Y (-7N) axes, apply holding force on Z axis (5N), and clockwise twisting torque about Z axis (0.2 Nm); no motion about X and Y angular axes."

# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [7, -7, 5, 0, 0, -0.2]

# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 10

# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 4
```

[end of motion plan]
message:
Given the user instruction and an image of the robot workspace, generate a structured physical plan for a robot end-effector interacting with the environment.
The task is to strangle the neck while grasping the neck.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.
Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
